A Huber Loss Minimization Approach to Byzantine Robust Federated Learning

Puning Zhao, Fei Yu, Zhiguo Wan
Zhejiang Lab
Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China
{pnzhao,yufei,wanzhiguo}@zhejianglab.com
Abstract

Federated learning systems are susceptible to adversarial attacks. To combat this, we introduce a novel aggregator based on Huber loss minimization, and provide a comprehensive theoretical analysis. Under independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) assumption, our approach has several advantages compared to existing methods. Firstly, it has optimal dependence on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, which stands for the ratio of attacked clients. Secondly, our approach does not need precise knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Thirdly, it allows different clients to have unequal data sizes. We then broaden our analysis to include non-i.i.d data, such that clients have slightly different distributions.

1 Introduction

Due to privacy concerns, there are a large number of isolated information islands, resulting in the difficulty of integrating data from various sources. Under such background, a novel machine learning framework called Federated Learning (FL) has arisen in recent years [1]. FL consists of numerous clients that store and compute data locally, and a central server that plays the role as a coordinator. In comparison to traditional centralized learning, FL offers distinct advantages in terms of both computational efficiency and privacy protection. As a result, FL is gaining increasing attention and has been widely applied in various domains, including mobile devices, industrial engineering, and healthcare [2, 3].

Nevertheless, FL is facing several severe challenges [4], with one of them being the robustness issue. Due to various factors, including data poisoning, system malfunctions and transmission errors, some clients may send wrong gradient vectors to the server. Consider that these abnormal behaviors are hard to predict and may happen in an unknown manner, it suffices to analyze the most harmful attack, which is typically modeled as Byzantine failure [5]. Under this model, an adversary can modify the gradient values uploaded to the master in arbitrary way. Without proper handling, even a single malicious client can significantly degrade the model performance [6]. Therefore, for the safe deployment of FL, it is important to design effective defense strategies robust to Byzantine attacks.

There have been many existing works on Byzantine robust federated learning problems. In particular, various gradient aggregators have been proposed. Krum [7] picks the gradient vector uploaded from clients with small nearest neighbor distances. However, the global convergence is not guaranteed. [8] proposed a geometric median-of-mean method, which ensures that the model weights converge to a point near to the global minimum, as long as ϵ<1/2italic-ϵ12\epsilon<1/2, with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon being the fraction of Byzantine machines. This method is not perfect since the error has a suboptimal rate of O~​(ϵ​d)~𝑂italic-ϵ𝑑\tilde{O}(\sqrt{\epsilon d}). [9] analyzed two aggregators. The first one, called coordinate-wise median, is suboptimal if the sample size per client n𝑛n is smaller than the number of clients m𝑚m. Unfortunately, this is quite likely in practice. The second one is coordinate-wise trimmed mean, which has optimal dependence with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is small. However, as will be discussed later, if ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2, then coordinate-wise trimmed mean is not efficient. Another drawback is that this method needs the precise knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, which is usually not practical. Moreover, the analysis of these previous methods are based on some simplified assumption, including independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) assumption, and that all clients have nearly equal sample sizes. More theoretical analysis is needed in realistic scenarios with heterogeneous and unbalanced data.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to Byzantine robust federated learning, which aggregates gradients by minimizing a multi-dimensional Huber loss. As a widely used loss function in robust statistics [10, 11, 12, 13], Huber loss combines the advantages of ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} and ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} loss, and achieves a tradeoff between robustness and consistency. However, the original definition of Huber loss was for scalars. We generalize the original definition, to make it suitable for vectors. In each iteration, given a list of gradient vectors uploaded from clients, the new algorithm obtains the estimated gradient of the underlying global risk function by minimizing the generalized Huber loss, and then use the outcome as the direction of parameter update.

We then provide theoretical analysis of the proposed method. To begin with, it is assumed that training samples are i.i.d, which is common in most of existing works on Byzantine robust FL [8, 7, 9]. Under i.i.d assumption, two error bounds are derived for balanced and unbalanced data, respectively. Consider that i.i.d assumption may not be realistic, we then make some generalization to allow heterogeneous clients. The result shows that our method is robust to moderate violation of i.i.d assumption. There are several recent works [14, 15, 16, 17] that deal with heterogeneous data. These works are mainly designed for the case that the differences between clients are large. In slightly heterogeneous regime, these methods can not achieve comparable statistical rates.

Finally, we discuss how to implement our new algorithm. Our design is motivated by Weiszfeld’s algorithm for calculating the geometric median of a set of vectors [18]. We make some adjustments to Weiszfeld’s algorithm, such that it can minimize the multi-dimensional Huber loss.

In general, compared with existing methods, our new approach has several advantages. Firstly, the dependence of statistical risk on the attack ratio ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is nearly minimax optimal, up to a logarithm factor. Secondly, our method has desirable performance with unbalanced data. In particular, with an adaptive rule of parameter selection, the statistical rate is the same as the case with balanced data. Thirdly, many existing methods require the precise knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon to set parameters, which is usually not practical. On the contrary, our method works well under the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-agnostic settings.

Our contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    A multi-dimensional Huber loss minimization approach to robust federated learning;

  • •

    Theoretical analysis of our method for both balanced and unbalanced data under i.i.d assumption, which also provides a guideline of parameter selection;

  • •

    Extension of the analysis above to heterogeneous clients;

  • •

    An implementation algorithm of multi-dimensional Huber loss minimization;

  • •

    Numerical experiments on both synthesized and real data, which validates the effectiveness of our new method.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. The problem statement and the proposed method are shown in Section 2. The theoretical analysis with and without i.i.d assumption are shown in Section 3 and 4, respectively. In Section 5, we describe our implementation algorithm. Furthermore, we compare our approach with existing methods in Section 6. Finally, numerical experiments and concluding remarks are shown in Section 7 and 8, respectively.

2 The Proposed Method

In this section, we make a precise statement of the framework of the federated learning problem, and then introduce our proposed aggregator based on minimization of multi-dimensional Huber loss.

The framework is shown in Algorithm 1. Suppose there is a server S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} and m𝑚m clients S1,…,Smsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑚S_{1},\ldots,S_{m}. Denote ℬℬ\mathcal{B} as the set of Byzantine clients. There are N𝑁N training samples in total, with each client Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} storing nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} of them. Denote 𝐙i​jsubscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\mathbf{Z}_{ij} as the j𝑗j-th sample in the i𝑖i-th client, j∈{1,…,ni}𝑗1…subscript𝑛𝑖j\in\{1,\ldots,n_{i}\}. Let f​(𝐰,𝐳)𝑓𝐰𝐳f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{z}) be the loss function of model parameter 𝐰∈𝒲𝐰𝒲\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W} with respect to sample 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z}, in which 𝒲⊂ℝd𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{W}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is the parameter space. Moreover, define the global risk function as

F​(𝐰)=𝔼​[f​(𝐰,𝐙)],𝐹𝐰𝔼delimited-[]𝑓𝐰𝐙\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w})=\mathbb{E}[f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z})], (1)

in which 𝐙𝐙\mathbf{Z} follows the global distribution of training samples. In particular, under i.i.d assumption, 𝐙𝐙\mathbf{Z} just follows the distribution of arbitrary 𝐙i​jsubscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\mathbf{Z}_{ij}. Otherwise, with heterogeneous clients, 𝐙𝐙\mathbf{Z} follows the average distribution of clients weighted by nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}. The goal is to learn the global minimizer

𝐰∗=arg⁡min𝐰∈𝒲​F​(𝐰).superscript𝐰𝐰𝒲𝐹𝐰\displaystyle\mathbf{w}^{*}=\underset{\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}}{\arg\min}F(\mathbf{w}). (2)

The algorithm starts with an initial parameter 𝐰0∈𝒲subscript𝐰0𝒲\mathbf{w}_{0}\in\mathcal{W}, At each iteration t=0,1,…𝑡01…t=0,1,\ldots, we find an update 𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{t+1}. Ideally, it would be better if we know ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}), so that we can use a simple gradient descent to update 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, i.e. 𝐰t+1=𝐰t−η​∇F​(𝐰t)subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}), in which η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. However, ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is unknown in practice. We need to estimate it using the gradient vectors uploaded from clients. Therefore, at each iteration t𝑡t, the master broadcasts parameter 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} to all clients, and then wait for the responses from them. Benign clients send the estimated gradient vectors back to the master, with respect to parameter 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t}. On the contrary, Byzantine clients send arbitrary vectors determined by the adversary. To be more precise, denote 𝐗i​tsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑡\mathbf{X}_{it} as the vector received from client i𝑖i at the t𝑡t-th iteration, then

𝐗i​tsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{X}_{it} =\displaystyle= {1ni​∑j=1ni∇f​(𝐰t,𝐙i​j)ifi∉ℬ⋆ifi∈ℬ,cases1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐙𝑖𝑗if𝑖ℬ⋆if𝑖ℬ\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t},\mathbf{Z}_{ij})&\text{if}&i\notin\mathcal{B}\\ \star&\text{if}&i\in\mathcal{B},\end{array}\right. (5)

in which ⋆⋆\star means arbitrary vector determined by the adversary. After received 𝐗i​tsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑡\mathbf{X}_{it} for all i=1,…,m𝑖1…𝑚i=1,\ldots,m, the master then updates the parameter 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} according to the following rule:

𝐰t+1=Π𝒲​(𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)),subscript𝐰𝑡1subscriptΠ𝒲subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})), (6)

in which Π𝒲​(⋅)subscriptΠ𝒲⋅\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\cdot) is an Euclidean projection operator, which ensures that the model parameter stays in 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}. This operator is also used in [9, 19]. η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. g​(𝐰t)𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is the aggregator function, which estimates ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) using 𝐗i​tsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑡\mathbf{X}_{it}, i=1,…,m𝑖1…𝑚i=1,\ldots,m.

Now it remains to design the aggregator function g​(𝐰t)𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Our idea is to minimize the Huber loss weighted by the sample sizes in each clients:

g​(𝐰t)=arg⁡min𝑠​∑i=1mni​ϕi​(∥𝐬−𝐗i​t∥),𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖delimited-∥∥𝐬subscript𝐗𝑖𝑡\displaystyle g(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{i=1}^{m}n_{i}\phi_{i}(\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\mathbf{X}_{it}\right\rVert), (7)

in which ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert is the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm, and

ϕi​(u)={12​u2if|u|≤TiTi​u−12​Ti2if|u|>Tisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑢cases12superscript𝑢2if𝑢subscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝑇𝑖𝑢12superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖2if𝑢subscript𝑇𝑖\displaystyle\phi_{i}(u)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}\frac{1}{2}u^{2}&\text{if}&|u|\leq T_{i}\\ T_{i}u-\frac{1}{2}T_{i}^{2}&\text{if}&|u|>T_{i}\end{array}\right. (10)

is the Huber loss function. If clients have equal or nearly equal sample size nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}, then we can let Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} to be the same for all i𝑖i. Otherwise, we may use different Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i}. With larger nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}, we let Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} to be smaller. We refer detailed discussion on parameter selection to Section 3 and 4.

Now we explain the intuition of such design. We have two requirements for a good aggregator: consistency without attack, and robustness under attack. Minimizing ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} loss corresponds to a simple averaging ga​v​g​(𝐰t)=(1/m)​∑i=1ni𝐗i​tsubscript𝑔𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝐗𝑖𝑡g_{avg}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=(1/m)\sum_{i=1}^{n_{i}}\mathbf{X}_{it}, which is consistent without attack, but not robust. On the contrary, minimizing ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} loss yields the geometric median of 𝐗i​tsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑡\mathbf{X}_{it}, i=1,…,m𝑖1…𝑚i=1,\ldots,m, which is robust but not consistent even without attack. Therefore, we minimize Huber loss, which combines the advantages of these two methods. At the limit Ti→∞→subscript𝑇𝑖T_{i}\rightarrow\infty, ϕisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi_{i} becomes ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} loss, then g​(𝐰t)𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is just the sample mean ga​v​g​(𝐰t)subscript𝑔𝑎𝑣𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡g_{avg}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). The opposite limit is Ti→0→subscript𝑇𝑖0T_{i}\rightarrow 0, under which g​(𝐰t)𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is actually the weighted geometric median of 𝐗i​tsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑡\mathbf{X}_{it}, i=1,…,m𝑖1…𝑚i=1,\ldots,m. Between these two extremes, we can set appropriate Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} to achieve a good tradeoff between consistency and Byzantine robustness.

In the following sections, we provide a theoretical analysis of the performance of our method. Following previous works [9, 19], we discuss three cases separately, which are stated in Assumption 1:

Assumption 1.

Consider the following three types of global loss function F𝐹F:

(a) (Strong convex) F𝐹F is μ𝜇\mu-strong convex and L𝐿L-smooth, and 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} is convex;

(b) (General convex) F𝐹F is convex and L𝐿L-smooth, with 𝒲={𝐰|∥𝐰−𝐰∗∥≤2​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥}𝒲conditional-set𝐰delimited-∥∥𝐰superscript𝐰2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰\mathcal{W}=\{\mathbf{w}|\left\lVert\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq 2\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\};

(c) (Non-convex) F𝐹F is L𝐿L-smooth, and ∥∇F​(𝐰)∥≤Mdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹𝐰𝑀\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert\leq M for all 𝐰∈𝒲𝐰𝒲\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}.

For all these three cases, we make the following common assumption on the covering number, which ensures the uniform convergence of the aggregator function:

Assumption 2.

Assume that there exists constants CWsubscript𝐶𝑊C_{W}, rDsubscript𝑟𝐷r_{D}, such that for all r<rD𝑟subscript𝑟𝐷r<r_{D}, the r𝑟r-covering of 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} is bounded by Nc​(r)≤CW/rdsubscript𝑁𝑐𝑟subscript𝐶𝑊superscript𝑟𝑑N_{c}(r)\leq C_{W}/r^{d}.

Before diving into the detailed analysis, we clarify the notations used in the remainder of this paper first.

Notations. Throughout this paper, we use the following notations: a≲bless-than-or-similar-to𝑎𝑏a\lesssim b if there exists a constant C𝐶C such that a≤C​b𝑎𝐶𝑏a\leq Cb. C𝐶C may depend on μ𝜇\mu, σ𝜎\sigma, L𝐿L and CWsubscript𝐶𝑊C_{W} in the assumptions. Conversely, a≳bgreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑎𝑏a\gtrsim b means a≥C​b𝑎𝐶𝑏a\geq Cb. Moreover, a∼bsimilar-to𝑎𝑏a\sim b means there exists two constants C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} such that C1​b≤a≤C2​bsubscript𝐶1𝑏𝑎subscript𝐶2𝑏C_{1}b\leq a\leq C_{2}b. Furthermore, a=O~​(b)𝑎~𝑂𝑏a=\tilde{O}(b) means a≤C​b​lnk⁡(N/δ)𝑎𝐶𝑏superscript𝑘𝑁𝛿a\leq Cb\ln^{k}(N/\delta) for some constants C𝐶C and k𝑘k. Denote [m]={1,…,m}delimited-[]𝑚1…𝑚[m]=\{1,\ldots,m\} as the set of numbers from 111 to m𝑚m. ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, q𝑞q are the ratio and the number of Byzantine clients, respectively, with q=ϵ​m𝑞italic-ϵ𝑚q=\epsilon m. Finally, ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert denotes ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm.

3 Theoretical Analysis for I.I.D Case

In this section, similar to most of previous works, we assume that all samples are i.i.d. We discuss two cases, depending on whether sample sizes are balanced in different clients.

Assumption 3.

𝐙i​jsubscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\mathbf{Z}_{ij} are i.i.d for all i=1,…,m𝑖1…𝑚i=1,\ldots,m and j=1,…,ni𝑗1…subscript𝑛𝑖j=1,\ldots,n_{i}. For any i𝑖i and j𝑗j, ∇f​(𝐰,𝐙i​j)∇𝑓𝐰subscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}) is sub-exponential with parameter σ𝜎\sigma, i.e.

sup‖𝐯‖=1​𝔼​[eλ​𝐯T​(∇f​(𝐰,𝐙i​j))−∇F​(𝐰)]≤e12​σ2​λ2, if ​|λ|≤1σformulae-sequencenorm𝐯1supremum𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝜆superscript𝐯𝑇∇𝑓𝐰subscript𝐙𝑖𝑗∇𝐹𝐰superscript𝑒12superscript𝜎2superscript𝜆2 if 𝜆1𝜎\displaystyle\underset{\|\mathbf{v}\|=1}{\sup}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{\lambda\mathbf{v}^{T}(\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}))-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})}\right]\leq e^{\frac{1}{2}\sigma^{2}\lambda^{2}},\text{ if }|\lambda|\leq\frac{1}{\sigma} (11)

for any vector 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} with ∥𝐯∥=1delimited-∥∥𝐯1\left\lVert\mathbf{v}\right\rVert=1;

Assumption 3 ensures that with high probability, using the true sample gradients, we are able to identify 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} defined in (2). Similar assumption was also made in [8, 20].

3.1 Balanced Data

In this case, we assume that ni=N/msubscript𝑛𝑖𝑁𝑚n_{i}=N/m for all i𝑖i, in which N𝑁N is the total number of training samples, and m𝑚m is the number of clients. Here we just denote n𝑛n as the number of samples per client, and the subscript i𝑖i is omitted. The analysis here can be simply generalized to the case in which nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} are different but are in the same order, i.e. there exists two constants c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2}, such that c1​n≤ni≤c2​nsubscript𝑐1𝑛subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑐2𝑛c_{1}n\leq n_{i}\leq c_{2}n. Since data sizes are balanced, we set equal thresholds in Huber losses, i.e. Ti=Tsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑇T_{i}=T for all i𝑖i.

We aim to obtain a bound of ∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert, the error of the estimation of global minimizer, that holds with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta. In particular, the following theorem holds. For the sake of simplicity, we state the asymptotic version here, while the finite sample bounds and proofs are shown in the appendix.

Theorem 1.

There exists two constants C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}, if

then under Assumption 2 and 3, with |ℬ|=ϵ​mℬitalic-ϵ𝑚|\mathcal{B}|=\epsilon m Byzantine clients, the following equations hold with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta.

(1) (Strong convex) Under Assumption 1(a), if η≤1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta\leq 1/L,

in which ρ=η​μ/2𝜌𝜂𝜇2\rho=\eta\mu/2;

F​(𝐰tm)−F​(𝐰∗)≤16​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥​ΔA;𝐹subscript𝐰subscript𝑡𝑚𝐹superscript𝐰16delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰subscriptΔ𝐴\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta_{A}; (14)

(3) (Non-convex) Under Assumption 1(c), with η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L, after tm=(2​L/ΔA2)​(F​(𝐰0)−F​(𝐰∗))subscript𝑡𝑚2𝐿superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐴2𝐹subscript𝐰0𝐹superscript𝐰t_{m}=(2L/\Delta_{A}^{2})(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})) steps, we have

mint=0,1,…,tm​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥≤2​ΔA,𝑡01…subscript𝑡𝑚delimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2subscriptΔ𝐴\displaystyle\underset{t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}}{\min}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{2}\Delta_{A}, (15)

in which

ΔA≲(11−2​ϵ​ϵn+1N)​d​ln⁡Nδ.less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptΔ𝐴112italic-ϵitalic-ϵ𝑛1𝑁𝑑𝑁𝛿\displaystyle\Delta_{A}\lesssim\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-2\epsilon}}\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\sqrt{d\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}. (16)

From (12), the selection of parameter T𝑇T does not rely on the knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Moreover, with fixed d𝑑d, if ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is small, our error bound O~​(ϵ/n+1/N)~𝑂italic-ϵ𝑛1𝑁\tilde{O}(\epsilon/\sqrt{n}+1/\sqrt{N}) is nearly optimal, since it matches the information-theoretic minimax lower bound up to a logarithm factor [9].

3.2 Unbalanced Data

Now we discuss a more realistic setting, such that nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} are different among clients. In this case, we design an adaptive selection rule of Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i}. For a benign client Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} with nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} samples, from central limit theorem, the distance between the gradient vector send to the server decays roughly with the squared root of nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}, i.e. ∥𝐗i​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰)∥∼d/nisimilar-todelimited-∥∥subscript𝐗𝑖𝐰∇𝐹𝐰𝑑subscript𝑛𝑖\left\lVert\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert\sim\sqrt{d/n_{i}} with high probability. Therefore, if nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is large and Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} is benign, then 𝐗i​(𝐰)subscript𝐗𝑖𝐰\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) should be close to most of other gradient vectors. If 𝐗i​(𝐰)subscript𝐗𝑖𝐰\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is far away from others, then client Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} is highly likely to be Byzantine. However, if nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is small, even if 𝐗i​(𝐰)subscript𝐗𝑖𝐰\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is far away from others, we can not infer that Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} is Byzantine, since the variance of 𝐗i​(𝐰)subscript𝐗𝑖𝐰\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is large even if Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} is benign. With such intuition, we set Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} to be smaller with large nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}, and vice versa.

To ensure the convergence, both the ratio of attacked clients and the ratio of the samples in attacked clients need to be small. Therefore, we slightly change the definition of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon as the maximum of the fraction of Byzantine clients, and the fraction of samples stored in Byzantine clients, i.e.

ϵ=max⁡{|ℬ|m,∑i∈ℬniN}.italic-ϵℬ𝑚subscript𝑖ℬsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑁\displaystyle\epsilon=\max\left\{\frac{|\mathcal{B}|}{m},\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}n_{i}}{N}\right\}. (17)

The theoretical results for unbalanced data is shown in Theorem 2.

Theorem 2.

Let

Ti=T0+Mni,subscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝑇0𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖\displaystyle T_{i}=T_{0}+\frac{M}{\sqrt{n_{i}}}, (18)

with M∼σ​d​ln⁡(N/δ)similar-to𝑀𝜎𝑑𝑁𝛿M\sim\sigma\sqrt{d\ln(N/\delta)}, and

ϵ​σ​m​dN​ln⁡Nδ≲T0≲σ​m​dN​ln⁡Nδ.less-than-or-similar-toitalic-ϵ𝜎𝑚𝑑𝑁𝑁𝛿subscript𝑇0less-than-or-similar-to𝜎𝑚𝑑𝑁𝑁𝛿\displaystyle\epsilon\sigma\sqrt{\frac{md}{N}\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}\lesssim T_{0}\lesssim\sigma\sqrt{\frac{md}{N}\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}. (19)

Then under Assumption 2 and 3, the following equations hold for small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon with probability 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta.

(1) (Strong convex) Under Assumption 1(a), if η≤1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta\leq 1/L,

∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥≤(1−ρ)t​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥+2​ΔAμ,delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰superscript1𝜌𝑡delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2subscriptΔ𝐴𝜇\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta_{A}}{\mu}, (20)

in which ρ=η​μ/2𝜌𝜂𝜇2\rho=\eta\mu/2;

(2) (General convex) Under Assumption 1(b), with η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L, after tm=(L/ΔB)​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥2subscript𝑡𝑚𝐿subscriptΔ𝐵subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2t_{m}=(L/\Delta_{B})\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert_{2} steps,

F​(𝐰tm)−F​(𝐰∗)≤16​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥​ΔB;𝐹subscript𝐰subscript𝑡𝑚𝐹superscript𝐰16delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰subscriptΔ𝐵\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta_{B}; (21)

(3) (Non-convex) Under Assumption 1(c), with η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L, after tm=(2​L/ΔB2)​(F​(𝐰0)−F​(𝐰∗))subscript𝑡𝑚2𝐿superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐵2𝐹subscript𝐰0𝐹superscript𝐰t_{m}=(2L/\Delta_{B}^{2})(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})) steps, we have

mint=0,1,…,tm​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥≤2​ΔB,𝑡01…subscript𝑡𝑚delimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2subscriptΔ𝐵\displaystyle\underset{t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}}{\min}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{2}\Delta_{B}, (22)

in which

ΔB≲(ϵ1−2​ϵ​mN+1N)​d​ln⁡Nδ.less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptΔ𝐵italic-ϵ12italic-ϵ𝑚𝑁1𝑁𝑑𝑁𝛿\displaystyle\Delta_{B}\lesssim\left(\frac{\epsilon}{1-2\epsilon}\sqrt{\frac{m}{N}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\sqrt{d\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}. (23)

Now we compare (23) with (16). If ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2, then the error is larger with unbalanced data sizes than the balanced case. In particular, the factor 1/(1−2​ϵ)112italic-ϵ1/(1-2\epsilon) in (23) is larger than the factor 1/1−2​ϵ112italic-ϵ1/\sqrt{1-2\epsilon} in (16). However, if ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is small, we can neglect the factor 1/(1−2​ϵ)112italic-ϵ1/(1-2\epsilon), thus the only difference between (23) and (16) is that the first term ϵ/nitalic-ϵ𝑛\epsilon/\sqrt{n} in the bracket in (16) is now replaced by ϵ​m/Nitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑁\epsilon\sqrt{m/N}. Recall that if samples are evenly distributed, then n=N/m𝑛𝑁𝑚n=N/m, thus these two bounds are actually of the same order. Therefore, we have shown a somewhat surprising result that the statistical error rate is not affected by the unbalanced allocation of training samples in clients.

4 Theoretical Analysis for Non-I.I.D Case

In this section, we assume that clients are heterogeneous. In particular, suppose that for any 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, μi​(𝐰)subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}), i=1,…,m𝑖1…𝑚i=1,\ldots,m are m𝑚m i.i.d random variables with 𝔼​[μi​(𝐰)]=F​(𝐰)𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰𝐹𝐰\mathbb{E}[\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w})]=F(\mathbf{w}). Furthermore, assume that 𝐙i​jsubscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\mathbf{Z}_{ij} for j=1,…,ni𝑗1…subscript𝑛𝑖j=1,\ldots,n_{i} are conditional independent given μi​(𝐰)subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}), and 𝔼​[∇f​(𝐰,𝐙i​j)|μi​(𝐰)]=μi​(𝐰)𝔼delimited-[]conditional∇𝑓𝐰subscript𝐙𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij})|\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w})]=\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}). Now we replace Assumption 3 with the following new assumption.

Assumption 4.

(a) μi​(𝐰)subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is sub-exponential with respect to ∇F​(𝐰)∇𝐹𝐰\nabla F(\mathbf{w}) with parameter σμsubscript𝜎𝜇\sigma_{\mu}, i.e.

sup∥𝐯∥=1​𝔼​[eλ​𝐯T​(μi​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰))]≤e12​σμ2​λ2, if ​|λ|≤1σμ;formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥𝐯1supremum𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝜆superscript𝐯𝑇subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰∇𝐹𝐰superscript𝑒12superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜇2superscript𝜆2 if 𝜆1subscript𝜎𝜇\displaystyle\underset{\left\lVert\mathbf{v}\right\rVert=1}{\sup}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{\lambda\mathbf{v}^{T}(\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}))}\right]\leq e^{\frac{1}{2}\sigma_{\mu}^{2}\lambda^{2}},\text{ if }|\lambda|\leq\frac{1}{\sigma_{\mu}}; (24)

(b) 𝐙i​jsubscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\mathbf{Z}_{ij} is sub-exponential with respect to μi​(𝐰)subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}) with parameter σ𝜎\sigma, i.e.

sup∥𝐯∥=1​𝔼​[eλ​𝐯T​(∇f​(𝐰,𝐙i​j)−μi​(𝐰))]≤e12​σ2​λ2, if ​|λ|≤1σ,formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥𝐯1supremum𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝜆superscript𝐯𝑇∇𝑓𝐰subscript𝐙𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰superscript𝑒12superscript𝜎2superscript𝜆2 if 𝜆1𝜎\displaystyle\underset{\left\lVert\mathbf{v}\right\rVert=1}{\sup}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{\lambda\mathbf{v}^{T}(\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij})-\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}))}\right]\leq e^{\frac{1}{2}\sigma^{2}\lambda^{2}},\text{ if }|\lambda|\leq\frac{1}{\sigma}, (25)

in which 𝐙i​jsubscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\mathbf{Z}_{ij}, j=1,…,ni𝑗1…subscript𝑛𝑖j=1,\ldots,n_{i} are conditional i.i.d given μi​(𝐰)subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}).

Assumption 4(a) allows heterogeneous data. However, μi​(𝐰)subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}) follows a sub-exponential distribution with parameter σμsubscript𝜎𝜇\sigma_{\mu}, thus the distance can not be too large. (b) requires that within each client, 𝐙i​jsubscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\mathbf{Z}_{ij} is sub-exponential with respect to μi​(𝐰)subscript𝜇𝑖𝐰\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}) for client i𝑖i. At the limit of σμ→0→subscript𝜎𝜇0\sigma_{\mu}\rightarrow 0, Assumption 4 reduces to Assumption 3. Some existing works assume that the clients are completely different, such as [16], which groups clients into some clusters with inherently different properties. However, we assume that training samples are collected from sources that are only moderately different. The theoretical result is shown as following.

Theorem 3.

Let Ti=T0​a+T0​b+M/nisubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝑇0𝑎subscript𝑇0𝑏𝑀subscript𝑛𝑖T_{i}=T_{0a}+T_{0b}+M/\sqrt{n_{i}}, with M∼σ​d​ln⁡(N/δ)similar-to𝑀𝜎𝑑𝑁𝛿M\sim\sigma\sqrt{d\ln(N/\delta)}, and

ϵ​σ​(m​d/N)​ln⁡(N/δ)≲T0​a≲σ​(m​d/N)​ln⁡(N/δ),less-than-or-similar-toitalic-ϵ𝜎𝑚𝑑𝑁𝑁𝛿subscript𝑇0𝑎less-than-or-similar-to𝜎𝑚𝑑𝑁𝑁𝛿\displaystyle\epsilon\sigma\sqrt{(md/N)\ln(N/\delta)}\lesssim T_{0a}\lesssim\sigma\sqrt{(md/N)\ln(N/\delta)}, (26)

and

T0​b∼σ​(d/N)​ln⁡(N/δ),similar-tosubscript𝑇0𝑏𝜎𝑑𝑁𝑁𝛿\displaystyle T_{0b}\sim\sigma\sqrt{(d/N)\ln(N/\delta)}, (27)

then under Assumption 2 and 4, the following equations holds with probability at least 1−2​δ12𝛿1-2\delta.

(1) (Strong convex) Under Assumption 1(a), with η≤1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta\leq 1/L,

∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥≤(1−ρ)t​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥+2​ΔCμ,delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰superscript1𝜌𝑡delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2subscriptΔ𝐶𝜇\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta_{C}}{\mu}, (28)

in which ρ=η​μ/2𝜌𝜂𝜇2\rho=\eta\mu/2;

(2) (General convex) Under Assumption 1(b), with η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L, after tm=(L/ΔC)​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥2subscript𝑡𝑚𝐿subscriptΔ𝐶subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2t_{m}=(L/\Delta_{C})\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert_{2} steps,

F​(𝐰tm)−F​(𝐰∗)≤16​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥​ΔC;𝐹subscript𝐰subscript𝑡𝑚𝐹superscript𝐰16delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰subscriptΔ𝐶\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta_{C}; (29)

(3) (Non-convex) Under Assumption 1(c), with η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L, after tm=(2​L/ΔC2)​(F​(𝐰0)−F​(𝐰∗))subscript𝑡𝑚2𝐿superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐶2𝐹subscript𝐰0𝐹superscript𝐰t_{m}=(2L/\Delta_{C}^{2})(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})) steps, we have

mint=0,1,…,tm​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥≤2​ΔC,𝑡01…subscript𝑡𝑚delimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2subscriptΔ𝐶\displaystyle\underset{t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}}{\min}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{2}\Delta_{C}, (30)

in which

ΔCsubscriptΔ𝐶\displaystyle\Delta_{C} ≲less-than-or-similar-to\displaystyle\lesssim (ϵ1−2​ϵ​mN+1N+σμ​∑i=1mni2N)​d​ln⁡Nδ+ϵ​σμ​d​ln⁡Nδ.italic-ϵ12italic-ϵ𝑚𝑁1𝑁subscript𝜎𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖2𝑁𝑑𝑁𝛿italic-ϵsubscript𝜎𝜇𝑑𝑁𝛿\displaystyle\left(\frac{\epsilon}{1-2\epsilon}\sqrt{\frac{m}{N}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}+\frac{\sigma_{\mu}\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{m}n_{i}^{2}}}{N}\right)\sqrt{d\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}+\epsilon\sigma_{\mu}d\ln\frac{N}{\delta}. (31)

5 Implementation

Our design follows the Weiszfeld’s algorithm for geometric median [18]. Suppose there are m𝑚m vectors, 𝐗1,…,𝐗msubscript𝐗1…subscript𝐗𝑚\mathbf{X}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{X}_{m}. Define

𝐜=arg⁡min𝑠​∑i=1mϕi​(∥𝐬−𝐗i∥)𝐜𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖delimited-∥∥𝐬subscript𝐗𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{c}=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\phi_{i}(\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\mathbf{X}_{i}\right\rVert) (32)

as the center that minimizes the multi-dimensional Huber loss, in which ϕisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi_{i} is defined in (10). Suppose that the algorithm starts from 𝐜0subscript𝐜0\mathbf{c}_{0}. Then the update rule is

𝐜k+1=∑i=1mmin⁡{1,Ti∥𝐜k−𝐗i∥}​𝐗i∑i=1mmin⁡{1,Ti∥𝐜k−𝐗i∥}.subscript𝐜𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚1subscript𝑇𝑖delimited-∥∥subscript𝐜𝑘subscript𝐗𝑖subscript𝐗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚1subscript𝑇𝑖delimited-∥∥subscript𝐜𝑘subscript𝐗𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{c}_{k+1}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\min\left\{1,\frac{T_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{c}_{k}-\mathbf{X}_{i}\right\rVert}\right\}\mathbf{X}_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\min\left\{1,\frac{T_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{c}_{k}-\mathbf{X}_{i}\right\rVert}\right\}}. (33)

Our algorithm repeats (33) until convergence. Similar to Weiszfeld’s algorithm, despite the fast convergence in almost all practical cases, it is not theoretically guaranteed in general. In section 8 in [21], it is shown that under some assumptions, an estimate of geometric median with Weiszfeld’s algorithm with error tolerance τ𝜏\tau needs O​(1/τ)𝑂1𝜏O(1/\tau) steps. With minor modification, the analysis in [21] also holds for our new algorithm (33). Moreover, from (33), each step requires O​(m​d)𝑂𝑚𝑑O(md) time, thus the overall time complexity is O​(m​d/τ)𝑂𝑚𝑑𝜏O(md/\tau).

In the future, it is possible to extend some recent works on geometric median, such as [22, 23] to improve the update rule (33) for multi-dimensional Huber loss minimization.

6 Comparison with Related Work

Now we compare our results with several existing popular approaches, including Krum [7], geometric median-of-means [8] (GMM), coordinate-wise median [9] (CWM), coordinate-wise trimmed mean [9] (CWTM), and recent methods based on high dimensional robust statistics [24, 19] (HDRS). To begin with, we consider the i.i.d case. In particular, we compare the following five aspects listed as following:

  • •

    Whether the method relies on precise knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon;

  • •

    Under sub-exponential and strong convex assumption, with sufficiently large number of iterations t𝑡t, whether the statistical error rate of ∥𝐰^−𝐰∗∥delimited-∥∥^𝐰superscript𝐰\left\lVert\hat{\mathbf{w}}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert is optimal (or nearly optimal up to a logarithm factor) in ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Here the optimal rate is ϵ/n+d/Nitalic-ϵ𝑛𝑑𝑁\epsilon/\sqrt{n}+\sqrt{d/N} [25, 9];

  • •

    Whether the performance is good if ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2. In particular, whether error blows up by a factor of no more than 1/1−2​ϵ112italic-ϵ1/\sqrt{1-2\epsilon}, as is shown in (16);

  • •

    Whether the time complexity of aggregator is linear or nearly linear, i.e. O​(m)𝑂𝑚O(m) or O​(m​log⁡m)𝑂𝑚𝑚O(m\log m);

  • •

    Whether the error rate is optimal in dimensionality d𝑑d;

The results are shown in Table 1, in which the five aspects mentioned above correspond to its five columns.

For the first aspect, only coordinate-wise median and our method do not rely on precise knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. For other methods, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon significantly affects the parameter selection. For example, coordinate-wise trimmed mean need to set the trim threshold to be ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in both sides. However, it is quite unlikely to have exact knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in practice. If an upper bound α𝛼\alpha is known, such that ϵ<αitalic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon<\alpha, then α𝛼\alpha can be used to set the parameter, but the accuracy will be sacrificed. Secondly, for optimal dependence in ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, Krum is not guaranteed to converge globally. Coordinate-wise median is not optimal if n≲mless-than-or-similar-to𝑛𝑚n\lesssim m. Geometric median-of-mean only has a O~​(ϵ​d/n)~𝑂italic-ϵ𝑑𝑛\tilde{O}(\sqrt{\epsilon d/n}) dependence. Thirdly, for the performance with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon close to 1/2121/2, coordinate-wise trimmed mean is not optimal. In particular, the error rate ΔC​W​T​MsubscriptΔ𝐶𝑊𝑇𝑀\Delta_{CWTM}, which plays the same role as ΔAsubscriptΔ𝐴\Delta_{A} in Theorem 1, is

ΔC​W​T​M=O~​(d1−2​ϵ​(ϵn+1N)),subscriptΔ𝐶𝑊𝑇𝑀~𝑂𝑑12italic-ϵitalic-ϵ𝑛1𝑁\displaystyle\Delta_{CWTM}=\tilde{O}\left(\frac{d}{1-2\epsilon}\left(\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\right), (34)

which blows up by a factor of 1/(1−2​ϵ)112italic-ϵ1/(1-2\epsilon), higher than 1/1−2​ϵ112italic-ϵ1/\sqrt{1-2\epsilon}. Intuitively, with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon close to 1/2121/2, coordinate-wise trimmed mean is not efficient because it removes most of samples, thus somewhat wastes the data. For the fourth column in Table 1, the time complexity has been discussed in previous section.

The only drawback of our method is that the dependence on d𝑑d is not optimal. In recent years, there are some new proposed methods for high dimensional robust mean estimation [26, 27, 28]. These methods can be used as the aggregator function in federated learning [29, 24, 19, 30], so that the dependence on d𝑑d becomes optimal. However, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon dependence is ϵitalic-ϵ\sqrt{\epsilon}, which is optimal only if we merely require the covariance matrix to have bounded operator norms. Under a more restrictive sub-exponential assumption, the convergence can not be further improved. Moreover, the time complexity is much higher.

One may wonder if it is possible to design an aggregator that satisfy all of the five properties listed in Table 1. However, [25] has shown that for robust mean estimation problem, as long as P≠N​P𝑃𝑁𝑃P\neq NP, under sub-exponential assumption, polynomial time complexity, optimal dependence in ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, and constant factor in d𝑑d are three goals that can not be achieved together. Since FL relies on robust mean estimation of gradient vectors as the aggregator function, we conjecture that it is impossible to satisfy all five properties in Table 1.

Right now we have compared our results with existing methods under i.i.d assumptions. There are also some related work focusing on non-i.i.d cases, but the assumptions are crucially different. For example, [14] proposed RSA. Instead of designing a gradient aggregator, [14] conducts model aggregation, which tries to reach a consensus between different models. This method is suitable for the cases in which the distributions in clients are significantly different. However, under the i.i.d limit, [14] does not have bounds comparable to existing methods under i.i.d assumption.

7 Numerical Results

This section shows numerical experiments. Despite the fact that our method has the advantage of not relying on knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, in this section, we just assume that all baseline methods know ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon exactly, including Krum, GMM, CWM and CWTM mentioned in the previous section. Parameters of these methods are all optimally selected with the precise knowledge of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. If ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is unknown, then the advantage of our method should be larger than what is described in this section. The detailed algorithms and parameter selection rules are:

Krum [7]: Let k=m−q−2𝑘𝑚𝑞2k=m-q-2, with q𝑞q being the number of Byzantine clients, then Krum picks i∗superscript𝑖i^{*} as

i∗=arg⁡mini∈[m]​∑j=1k∥𝐗i−𝐗i(j)∥2,superscript𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑗2\displaystyle i^{*}=\underset{i\in[m]}{\arg\min}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\left\lVert\mathbf{X}_{i}-\mathbf{X}_{i}^{(j)}\right\rVert^{2}, (35)

in which 𝐗i(j)superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑗\mathbf{X}_{i}^{(j)} is the j𝑗j-th nearest neighbor of 𝐗isubscript𝐗𝑖\mathbf{X}_{i} among {𝐗1,…,𝐗m}subscript𝐗1…subscript𝐗𝑚\{\mathbf{X}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{X}_{m}\}. Then

gK​r​u​m​(𝐰)=Xi⁣∗.subscript𝑔𝐾𝑟𝑢𝑚𝐰subscript𝑋𝑖\displaystyle g_{Krum}(\mathbf{w})=X_{i*}. (36)

Geometric median-of-mean (GMM) [8]. It randomly divides m𝑚m vectors from clients into b𝑏b batches, and then calculate geometric median of the mean gradients of these batches:

gG​M​M​(𝐰)=arg⁡min𝑠​∑j=1b∥𝐬−1|Aj|​∑i∈Aj𝐗i∥.subscript𝑔𝐺𝑀𝑀𝐰𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑏delimited-∥∥𝐬1subscript𝐴𝑗subscript𝑖subscript𝐴𝑗subscript𝐗𝑖\displaystyle g_{GMM}(\mathbf{w})=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{j=1}^{b}\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\frac{1}{|A_{j}|}\sum_{i\in A_{j}}\mathbf{X}_{i}\right\rVert. (37)

In our experiments, following [8], we set b=2​q+1𝑏2𝑞1b=2q+1, in which q𝑞q is the number of Byzantine clients.

Coordinate-wise median (CWM)[9]. This is an aggregation rule that calculates the element-wise median of vectors 𝐗1,…,𝐗msubscript𝐗1…subscript𝐗𝑚\mathbf{X}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{X}_{m}.

Coordinate-wise trimmed mean (CWTM)[9]. We assume that ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is known. In each dimension, CWTM removes the largest and smallest ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon fraction of values and then calculate the element-wise mean.

Ideally, robustness against Byzantine failure needs to be tested using optimal attack strategies. However, the optimization problems are hard to solve. In this section, we use four attack strategies. One of them is a simple sign-flip attack, which flips the sign of gradient vectors. Other three are some approximate strategies that are tailored to specific aggregators, including Krum Attack (KA) and Trimmed Mean Attack (TMA) described in [31] that are nearly optimal for Krum and CWTM, respectively. Moreover, for a fair comparison, we have designed an attack strategy for our new proposed method, called Huber Loss Minimization Attack (HLMA). Here we provide the details of all these attacks.

Denote

g0​(𝐰t)=1m​∑i=1m𝐆i​(𝐰t),subscript𝑔0subscript𝐰𝑡1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝐆𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}), (38)

with

𝐆i​(𝐰t)=1ni​∑j=1ni∇f​(𝐰t,𝐙i​j).subscript𝐆𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}). (39)

Let 𝐬t=sign⁡(g0​(𝐰t))subscript𝐬𝑡signsubscript𝑔0subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{s}_{t}=\operatorname{sign}(g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t})) to be the element-wise sign of g0​(𝐰t)subscript𝑔0subscript𝐰𝑡g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). We solve the following optimization problem:

maxπA​𝐬T​(g0​(𝐰t)−g​(𝐰t)),subscript𝜋𝐴superscript𝐬𝑇subscript𝑔0subscript𝐰𝑡𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle\underset{\pi_{A}}{\max}\mathbf{s}^{T}(g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-g(\mathbf{w}_{t})), (40)

in which πAsubscript𝜋𝐴\pi_{A} is the attack strategy. Such formulation follows [31]. The intuition is to make the aggregated gradient should be as far away from the ground truth ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) (approximated by g0(𝐰t))g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t}))) as possible. Moreover, in each coordinate, it would be better if g​(𝐰t)𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is moved towards the opposite direction to g0​(𝐰t)subscript𝑔0subscript𝐰𝑡g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t}), such that the model updates along a wrong direction. Our design of Krum attack and Trimmed mean attack follows [31].

Krum Attack (KA). KA maximizes λ𝜆\lambda, such that with all attacked samples placed at g0​(𝐰t)−λ​𝐬subscript𝑔0subscript𝐰𝑡𝜆𝐬g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\lambda\mathbf{s}, Krum selects one of these attacked samples as the aggregated gradient according to (35). Practically, we set λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1 first, and then repeat with λ←λ/2←𝜆𝜆2\lambda\leftarrow\lambda/2 until Krum selects one of attacked samples, or λ<10−4𝜆superscript104\lambda<10^{-4}.

Trimmed Mean Attack (TMA). Denote Xi​t,jsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑡𝑗X_{it,j} as the j𝑗j-th element of 𝐗i​jsubscript𝐗𝑖𝑗\mathbf{X}_{ij}, and

Gi​j​(𝐰t)=1ni​∑j=1ni∂jf​(𝐰t,𝐙i​j).subscript𝐺𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑗𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\displaystyle G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\partial_{j}f(\mathbf{w}_{t},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}). (41)

Then the attack strategy is

Xi​t,j={maxi∈[m]​Gi​j​(𝐰t)ifs=−1mini∈[m]​Gi​j​(𝐰t)ifs=1.subscript𝑋𝑖𝑡𝑗cases𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝐺𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡if𝑠1𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝐺𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡if𝑠1\displaystyle X_{it,j}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}\underset{i\in[m]}{\max}G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})&\text{if}&s=-1\\ \underset{i\in[m]}{\min}G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})&\text{if}&s=1.\end{array}\right. (44)

It has been discussed in [31] that the TMA is also optimal for coordinate-wise median.

Huber Loss Minimization Attack (HLMA). We let

Xi​t,j={Gi​j​(𝐰t)+Tdifs=−1Gi​j​(𝐰t)−Tdifs=1.subscript𝑋𝑖𝑡𝑗casessubscript𝐺𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡𝑇𝑑if𝑠1subscript𝐺𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡𝑇𝑑if𝑠1\displaystyle X_{it,j}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\frac{T}{\sqrt{d}}&\text{if}&s=-1\\ G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\frac{T}{\sqrt{d}}&\text{if}&s=1.\end{array}\right. (47)

In Section 7.1 and 7.2, we show simple experiments on some synthesized data and MNIST data, respectively. In these two sections, samples are i.i.d and data allocation is balanced.

7.1 Synthesized Data

To begin with, we run experiments with distributed linear regression. The model is

Vj=⟨𝐔j,𝐰∗⟩+Wj,subscript𝑉𝑗subscript𝐔𝑗superscript𝐰subscript𝑊𝑗\displaystyle V_{j}=\langle\mathbf{U}_{j},\mathbf{w}^{*}\rangle+W_{j}, (48)

in which 𝐔j,𝐰∗∈ℝdsubscript𝐔𝑗superscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{U}_{j},\mathbf{w}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, with 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} being the true parameter, and Wjsubscript𝑊𝑗W_{j} is the noise following standard normal distribution. In this experiment, we set d=50𝑑50d=50. Firstly, we generate all elements of 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} from distribution 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01\mathcal{N}(0,1). We then obtain N=10,000𝑁10000N=10,000 samples (𝐔j,Vj)subscript𝐔𝑗subscript𝑉𝑗(\mathbf{U}_{j},V_{j}), j=1,…,N𝑗1…𝑁j=1,\ldots,N. These samples are evenly divided into m=500𝑚500m=500 clients. For baseline methods including Krum, GMM, CWTM, the parameters are all set optimally, according to the statements at the beginning of Section 7. Our new Huber loss minimization approach uses T=1𝑇1T=1 for all clients. We run 200200200 iterations in total, with learning rate η=0.02𝜂0.02\eta=0.02. The results are shown in Figure 1 for all four attack strategies mentioned above, in which we plot the square root of the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} regression loss against the number of iterations.

From Figure 1, it can be observed that our new method (red solid curve) works well for all four types of attacks, even with HLMA that is specifically designed for our method. On the contrary, from Figure 1 (b), Krum aggregator (blue dotted curve) fails under KA that is tailored to Krum. Moreover, (c) shows that under TMA which is designed for coordinate-wise trimmed mean, GMM and CWTM (dashed curves with orange and purple colors, respectively) perform significantly worse than our method. CWM appears to be robust, but the performance is not as good as our approach in general.

7.2 Real data

Now we use MNIST dataset [32], which has 60,0006000060,000 images of handwritten digits for training, and 12,0001200012,000 images for testing. The sizes of these images are 28×28282828\times 28. In this experiment, we use a neural network with one hidden layer between input and output. The size of hidden layer is 323232. Training samples are evenly allocated into m=500𝑚500m=500 clients. We set T=0.2𝑇0.2T=0.2 here. The results with ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2 is shown in Figure 2, in which we plot the curve of accuracy on the test data against the number of iterations.

Similar to synthesized data, experiments on MNIST show that our new method outperforms other methods. Krum is still highly susceptible to KA. CWM and CWTM appear to be only slightly worse than our method.

Now we increase ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon to 0.40.40.4. Other settings remain unchanged. This experiment shows the performance when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2. The results are shown in Figure 3.

Our method still exhibits desirable performance, even under HLMA designed specifically for ourselves. Krum works relatively well under sign-flip, TMA and HLMA, but fails under KA. The performance of GMM is relatively well for ϵ=0.4italic-ϵ0.4\epsilon=0.4. As has been discussed earlier, the drawback of GMM is the suboptimal statistical rate on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, which is serious for small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. However, when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2, this disadvantage becomes much less obvious. Moreover, under TMA and HLMA, the performance of coordinate-wise methods, including CWM and CWTM become significantly worse, especially the latter. This phenomenon agrees with the theoretical analysis, since in section 6, we have discussed that CWTM has suboptimal rate with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon close to 1/2121/2.

7.3 Unbalanced sample allocation

We then evaluate the adaptive selection rule (18) for unbalanced data. In this experiment, samples are still allocated in different clients randomly, but the sample sizes in different clients are no longer equal.

In this experiment, we use the following allocation rule.

(1) Randomly shuffle training samples. Denote the indices of samples after shuffling as 0,1,…,N−101…𝑁10,1,\ldots,N-1;

(2) Generate m−1𝑚1m-1 indices randomly from {0,…,N−1}0…𝑁1\{0,\ldots,N-1\} without replacement;

(3) Sort these m−1𝑚1m-1 indices in ascending order. Denote the results as b1,…,bm−1subscript𝑏1…subscript𝑏𝑚1b_{1},\ldots,b_{m-1}, such that b1<b2<…<bm−1subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2…subscript𝑏𝑚1b_{1}<b_{2}<\ldots<b_{m-1};

(4) Let b0=0subscript𝑏00b_{0}=0, bm=Nsubscript𝑏𝑚𝑁b_{m}=N. Allocate samples with bi≤j≤bi+1subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗subscript𝑏𝑖1b_{i}\leq j\leq b_{i+1} to client i𝑖i.

It can be shown that with increase of N𝑁N, the ratio of samples in each client follows Beta distribution 𝔹​(1,m)𝔹1𝑚\mathbb{B}(1,m).

We use Ti=2/nisubscript𝑇𝑖2subscript𝑛𝑖T_{i}=2/\sqrt{n_{i}} as the threshold of each clients. Other settings remain the same as previous experiments. For simplicity, we only show the result with HLMA in Figure 4.

The result shows that with unbalanced data and our adaptive choice of Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i}, the advantage of our method becomes more obvious, especially for MNIST data. The comparison of Figure 4(b) with Figure 2(d) shows that our method achieves nearly the same performance as the balanced case, while other methods are somewhat negatively affected by the unbalanced data allocation.

7.4 Heterogeneous Data

Finally, we show the robustness of our proposed method for non-i.i.d data. In particular, we make clients to be heterogeneous. We make some adjustment to the original linear model (48), such that in different machines, 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} are slightly different:

Vj=⟨𝐔j,𝐰∗+𝚫𝐰​(i)⟩+Wjsubscript𝑉𝑗subscript𝐔𝑗superscript𝐰subscript𝚫𝐰𝑖subscript𝑊𝑗\displaystyle V_{j}=\langle\mathbf{U}_{j},\mathbf{w}^{*}+\mathbf{\Delta}_{\mathbf{w}}(i)\rangle+W_{j} (49)

for all sample j𝑗j stored in client i𝑖i. Δ𝐰​(i)subscriptΔ𝐰𝑖\Delta_{\mathbf{w}}(i) is the additional weight for client i𝑖i. We let each component of Δ𝐰​(i)subscriptΔ𝐰𝑖\Delta_{\mathbf{w}}(i) follows distribution 𝒩​(0,0.2)𝒩00.2\mathcal{N}(0,0.2). Under this setting, conditional on Δ𝐰​(i)subscriptΔ𝐰𝑖\Delta_{\mathbf{w}}(i), samples within each clients are i.i.d. However, they are no longer i.i.d between different clients. The results are shown in Figure 5, in which we fix ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2 here.

According to Figure 5, with heterogeneous clients, our method still exhibits advantage compared to existing ones.

8 Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed a novel approach for Byzantine robust federated learning based on Huber loss minimization. Theoretical analyses have been conducted under the initial i.i.d assumption with balanced data, and subsequently extended to unbalanced and heterogeneous scenarios. Our method offers several advantages over existing approaches, including optimal statistical rate with fixed dimension, convenient selection of parameters without knowledge of Byzantine fraction ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, and suitability for clients with unbalanced data. Furthermore, we have presented an algorithm to implement the multi-dimensional Huber loss minimization. The effectiveness of our approach is validated by numerical experiments. There are several possible directions for further improvements in the future. For example, pre-processing by filtering some obvious outliers may help to reduce the effect of Byzantine clients. Moreover, it is also worthwhile to consider one-round or multi-round robust algorithms to reduce the communication cost.

Appendix A Common Lemmas on Convergence

Recall that the aggregator function is defined as

g​(𝐰t)=arg⁡min𝑠​∑i=1mni​ϕi​(∥𝐬−𝐗i​t∥).𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖delimited-∥∥𝐬subscript𝐗𝑖𝑡\displaystyle g(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{i=1}^{m}n_{i}\phi_{i}(\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\mathbf{X}_{it}\right\rVert). (50)

Now we generalize the definition above to arbitrary 𝐰∈𝒲𝐰𝒲\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}:

g​(𝐰)=arg⁡min𝑠​∑i=1mni​ϕi​(∥𝐬−𝐗i​(𝐰)∥),𝑔𝐰𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑛𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖delimited-∥∥𝐬subscript𝐗𝑖𝐰\displaystyle g(\mathbf{w})=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{i=1}^{m}n_{i}\phi_{i}(\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert), (51)

in which 𝐗i​(𝐰)subscript𝐗𝑖𝐰\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) denotes the signal from client i𝑖i, if the master broadcasts 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. In particular,

𝐗i​(𝐰)={𝐆i​(𝐰)ifi∉ℬ⋆ifi∈ℬ,subscript𝐗𝑖𝐰casessubscript𝐆𝑖𝐰if𝑖ℬ⋆if𝑖ℬ\displaystyle\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w})&\text{if}&i\notin\mathcal{B}\\ \star&\text{if}&i\in\mathcal{B},\end{array}\right. (54)

with

𝐆i​(𝐰)=1ni​∑j=1ni∇f​(𝐰,𝐙i​j).subscript𝐆𝑖𝐰1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖∇𝑓𝐰subscript𝐙𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}). (55)

Define

Δ=supπA​sup𝐰∈𝒲​∥g​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰)∥Δsubscript𝜋𝐴supremum𝐰𝒲supremumdelimited-∥∥𝑔𝐰∇𝐹𝐰\displaystyle\Delta=\underset{\pi_{A}}{\sup}\underset{\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}}{\sup}\left\lVert g(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert (56)

as the supremum error of gradient aggregator, in which πAsubscript𝜋𝐴\pi_{A} stands for the strategy of the adversary.

Then we show the following lemmas.

Lemma 1.

(Strong convex F𝐹F) If F𝐹F is μ𝜇\mu-strong convex and L𝐿L-smooth, 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} is a convex set, and 𝐰∗∈𝒲superscript𝐰𝒲\mathbf{w}^{*}\in\mathcal{W}, then with η≤1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta\leq 1/L,

∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥≤(1−ρ)t​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥+2​Δμ,delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰superscript1𝜌𝑡delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2Δ𝜇\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta}{\mu}, (57)

with

ρ=12​η​μ.𝜌12𝜂𝜇\displaystyle\rho=\frac{1}{2}\eta\mu. (58)
Proof.

The proof is shown in Section A.1. ∎

Lemma 2.

(General convex F𝐹F) If F𝐹F is convex and L𝐿L-smooth, and

𝒲={𝐰|∥𝐰−𝐰∗∥≤2​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥},𝒲conditional-set𝐰delimited-∥∥𝐰superscript𝐰2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰\displaystyle\mathcal{W}=\{\mathbf{w}|\left\lVert\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq 2\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\}, (59)

then with η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L, after tm=(L/Δ)​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥2subscript𝑡𝑚𝐿Δsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2t_{m}=(L/\Delta)\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert_{2} steps,

F​(𝐰tm)−F​(𝐰∗)≤16​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥​Δ.𝐹subscript𝐰subscript𝑡𝑚𝐹superscript𝐰16delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰Δ\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta. (60)
Proof.

The proof is shown in Section A.2. ∎

Lemma 3.

(Non-convex F𝐹F) If F𝐹F is L𝐿L-smooth, ∥∇F​(𝐰)∥≤Mdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹𝐰𝑀\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert\leq M for all 𝐰∈𝒲𝐰𝒲\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}, and

𝒲={𝐰|∥𝐰−𝐰∗∥≤2Δ2​(M+Δ)​(F​(𝐰0)−F​(𝐰∗))},𝒲conditional-set𝐰delimited-∥∥𝐰superscript𝐰2superscriptΔ2𝑀Δ𝐹subscript𝐰0𝐹superscript𝐰\displaystyle\mathcal{W}=\left\{\mathbf{w}|\left\lVert\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\frac{2}{\Delta^{2}}(M+\Delta)(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}))\right\}, (61)

then with η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L and

tm=2​LΔ2​(F​(𝐰0)−F​(𝐰∗)),subscript𝑡𝑚2𝐿superscriptΔ2𝐹subscript𝐰0𝐹superscript𝐰\displaystyle t_{m}=\frac{2L}{\Delta^{2}}(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})), (62)

we have

mint=0,1,…,tm​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥≤2​Δ.𝑡01…subscript𝑡𝑚delimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2Δ\displaystyle\underset{t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}}{\min}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{2}\Delta. (63)
Proof.

The proof is shown in Section A.3. ∎

A.1 Proof of Lemma 1

∥𝐰t+1−𝐰∗∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert =\displaystyle= ∥Π𝒲​(𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t))−𝐰∗∥delimited-∥∥subscriptΠ𝒲subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰\displaystyle\left\lVert\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}))-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert (64)
≤(a)𝑎\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{\leq} ∥𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert
≤\displaystyle\leq ∥𝐰t−η​∇F​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥+η​∥∇F​(𝐰t)−g​(𝐰t)∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰𝜂delimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert
≤(b)𝑏\displaystyle\overset{(b)}{\leq} ∥𝐰t−η​∇F​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥+η​Δ,delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰𝜂Δ\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta\Delta,

in which (a) uses the assumption that 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} is a convex set, which was made in the statement of Lemma 1. (b) uses (56). For the first term,

∥𝐰t−η​∇F​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2} (65)
=\displaystyle= ∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2−2​η​⟨𝐰t−𝐰∗,∇F​(𝐰t)⟩+η2​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰22𝜂subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝜂2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-2\eta\langle\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*},\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\rangle+\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
≤(a)𝑎\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{\leq} ∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2−2​η​(F​(𝐰t)−F​(𝐰∗)+μ2​∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2)+η2​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰22𝜂𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡𝐹superscript𝐰𝜇2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰2superscript𝜂2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-2\eta\left(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}\right)+\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
≤(b)𝑏\displaystyle\overset{(b)}{\leq} (1−η​μ)​∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2−2​η​(F​(𝐰t)−F​(𝐰∗))+2​η2​L​(F​(𝐰t)−F​(𝐰∗))1𝜂𝜇superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰22𝜂𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡𝐹superscript𝐰2superscript𝜂2𝐿𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡𝐹superscript𝐰\displaystyle(1-\eta\mu)\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-2\eta(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}))+2\eta^{2}L(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}))
≤(c)𝑐\displaystyle\overset{(c)}{\leq} (1−η​μ)​∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2.1𝜂𝜇superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰2\displaystyle(1-\eta\mu)\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}.

(a) comes from the μ𝜇\mu-strong convexity of F𝐹F, which ensures that

F​(𝐰∗)≥F​(𝐰t)+⟨∇F​(𝐰t),𝐰∗−𝐰t⟩+μ2​∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2.𝐹superscript𝐰𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰subscript𝐰𝑡𝜇2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\geq F(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\langle\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}),\mathbf{w}^{*}-\mathbf{w}_{t}\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}. (66)

(b) comes from the L𝐿L-smoothness of F𝐹F, which ensures that

∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥2≤2​L​(F​(𝐰t)−F​(𝐰∗)).superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡22𝐿𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡𝐹superscript𝐰\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}\leq 2L(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})). (67)

(c) is from the requirement η≤1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta\leq 1/L. Therefore, from (64) and (65),

∥𝐰t+1−𝐰∗∥≤1−η​μ​∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥+η​Δ.delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰1𝜂𝜇delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰𝜂Δ\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{1-\eta\mu}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta\Delta. (68)

By induction, it can be shown that

∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥≤(1−ρ)t​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥+2​Δμ,delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰superscript1𝜌𝑡delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2Δ𝜇\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta}{\mu}, (69)

with ρ=η​μ/2𝜌𝜂𝜇2\rho=\eta\mu/2.

A.2 Proof of Lemma 2

Our proof follows [9] and [19] with some slight improvements.

To begin with, we prove that 𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)∈𝒲subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡𝒲\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\in\mathcal{W} for t=1,…,tm−1𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑚1t=1,\ldots,t_{m}-1, such that the projection has no effect, i.e. Π𝒲​(𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t))=𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)subscriptΠ𝒲subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}))=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Note that

∥𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥≤∥𝐰t−η​∇F​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥+η​Δ.delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰𝜂Δ\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta\Delta. (70)

Recall that η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L,

∥𝐰t−η​∇F​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2} =\displaystyle= ∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2−2​η​⟨∇F​(𝐰t),𝐰t−𝐰∗⟩+η2​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰22𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰superscript𝜂2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-2\eta\langle\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}),\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\rangle+\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2} (71)
≤\displaystyle\leq ∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2−2​ηL​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥2+η2​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰22𝜂𝐿superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2superscript𝜂2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-\frac{2\eta}{L}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}+\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
=\displaystyle= ∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2−1L2​∥∇F​(𝐰t)∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰21superscript𝐿2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-\frac{1}{L^{2}}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
≤\displaystyle\leq ∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥2.superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}.

Therefore

∥𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥≤∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥+ΔL.delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰Δ𝐿\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{\Delta}{L}. (72)

Now prove that for t=0,1,…,tm−1𝑡01…subscript𝑡𝑚1t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}-1,

∥𝐰t−g​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥≤∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥+t​ΔLdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰𝑡Δ𝐿\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{t\Delta}{L} (73)

by induction. (73) for t=0𝑡0t=0 is trivial. If (73) holds for t𝑡t, then

∥𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥≤∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥+tm​ΔL≤2​∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥,delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰subscript𝑡𝑚Δ𝐿2delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{t_{m}\Delta}{L}\leq 2\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert, (74)

hence 𝐰t−g​(𝐰t)∈𝒲subscript𝐰𝑡𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡𝒲\mathbf{w}_{t}-g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\in\mathcal{W}, and 𝐰t+1=Π𝒲​(𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t))=𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)subscript𝐰𝑡1subscriptΠ𝒲subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}))=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Hence, at time step t+1𝑡1t+1,

∥𝐰t+1−η​g​(𝐰t+1)−𝐰∗∥≤∥𝐰t+1−𝐰∗∥+ΔL≤∥𝐰0−𝐰∗∥+(t+1)​ΔL.delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡1𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰Δ𝐿delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰0superscript𝐰𝑡1Δ𝐿\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{\Delta}{L}\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{(t+1)\Delta}{L}. (75)

A.3 Proof of Lemma 3

∥𝐰t−η​g​(𝐰t)−𝐰∗∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡𝜂𝑔subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert ≤\displaystyle\leq ∥𝐰t−𝐰∗∥+η​(∥∇F​(𝐰)∥+∥g​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰)∥)delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰𝜂delimited-∥∥∇𝐹𝐰delimited-∥∥𝑔𝐰∇𝐹𝐰\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta(\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert+\left\lVert g(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert) (88)

The proof is shown in Section B.1. ∎

Define

B.3 Proof of Lemma 6

From (104), we have

∑i=1m∇sϕ​(∥a​(𝐰)−𝐆i​(𝐰)∥)=𝟎.superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript∇𝑠italic-ϕdelimited-∥∥𝑎𝐰subscript𝐆𝑖𝐰0\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{m}\nabla_{s}\phi(\left\lVert a(\mathbf{w})-\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert)=\mathbf{0}. (128)

The proof of (2) in Lemma 12 is complete.

D.3 Proof of Lemma 14
